questionList.questionText: A 51-year-old man comes to the office for a regular health checkup.  He reports no symptoms.  Medical history includes type 2 diabetes mellitus diagnosed 2 years ago, which is being treated with metformin.  The patient has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years and drinks 1 or 2 beers most days of the week.  He works in construction.  Blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg and pulse is 72/min.  BMI is 29 kg/m2.  Physical examination is unremarkable.  Hemoglobin A1c is 7.6%.  Optimizing medical therapy for better glycemic control is discussed.  During the office visit, the patient reports that his older brother was recently diagnosed with pancreatic adenocarcinoma.  He is worried that he might also develop pancreatic cancer and inquires if there is something he can do to lower his risk.  Which of the following would be most helpful in reducing his risk for pancreatic cancer?
questionList.explanationText:
Major risk factors for pancreatic cancer

Hereditary

  • First-degree relative with pancreatic cancer
  • Hereditary pancreatitis
  • Germline mutations (eg, BRCA1, BRCA2, Peutz-Jeghers syndrome)

Environmental

  • Cigarette smoking (most significant)
  • Obesity, low physical activity
  • Nonhereditary chronic pancreatitis

Pancreatic adenocarcinoma (arising from the exocrine ducts) is the most common form of pancreatic cancer, primarily affecting older men.  It is usually diagnosed relatively late in the disease course (due to nonspecific initial symptoms) and has a high mortality rate (ie, 98%).

Cigarette smoking is a major modifiable risk factor for pancreatic cancer.  The risk for cancer increases significantly with the number of cigarettes consumed, and heavy smokers have a risk nearly 2-3 times higher than that of nonsmokers.  Smoking cessation may reduce pancreatic cancer deaths by 25%.  Other established modifiable risk factors include obesity, especially in association with sedentary lifestyle (and possibly consumption of heavily processed foods), and nonhereditary chronic pancreatitis.

In addition to modifiable risk factors for pancreatic cancer, hereditary factors include germline mutations (eg, BRCA1, BRCA2, Peutz-Jeghers syndrome) and familial pancreatic cancer syndromes (eg, first-degree relative with pancreatic cancer).  This patient may have a hereditary predisposition to pancreatic cancer given his brother's recent diagnosis; however, smoking cessation is still effective and recommended to reduce his lifetime risk (Choice C).

(Choice A)  Heavy alcohol consumption (eg, >6 drinks a day) may increase the risk of pancreatic cancer directly or indirectly by causing chronic pancreatis; however, this patient has light alcohol consumption.  By far, cigarette smoking use is the greatest modifiable risk factor for pancreatic cancer.

(Choice B)  This patient's occupation in construction may cause increased exposure to environmental radon, which increases the risk for lung cancer, not pancreatic cancer.

(Choice E)  Antioxidants (eg, vitamins C and E) can neutralize free radicals, which are created when the body is exposed to environmental insults (eg, tobacco, ultraviolet rays) and result in DNA damage and oncogenesis.  However, antioxidant supplementation has not been shown to decrease the risk for pancreatic cancer.

Educational objective:
Pancreatic cancer can be due to hereditary (eg, first-degree relative with pancreatic cancer, hereditary pancreatitis) or environmental (eg, cigarette smoking, obesity) risk factors.  Cigarette smoking is the most consistent reversible risk factor for pancreatic cancer.

questionList.title: Pancreatic cancer

questionList.questionText: A 55-year-old woman comes to the office due to pain, itching, and red streaks on her left arm.  The patient had a similar episode 2 weeks ago that affected her chest and resolved on its own.  Review of systems is positive for heartburn and mild upper abdominal pain for the past several months that is partially relieved by antacids.  She has a 30-pack-year history and drinks alcohol occasionally.  On physical examination, the patient has mild epigastric tenderness on palpation of the abdomen.  The lungs are clear to auscultation.  There are no murmurs on cardiac examination.  Tender, erythematous, and palpable cord-like veins are noted on the left arm and upper chest.  Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient's presentation suggests migratory superficial thrombophlebitis, also known as Trousseau syndrome.  Trousseau syndrome manifests with chronic disseminated intravascular coagulopathy and should be suspected in the setting of recurrent, superficial venous thrombosis at unusual sites (eg, arm, chest), as this patient experienced.  The syndrome is usually diagnosed prior to (sometimes months to years before) or at the same time as an occult visceral malignancy.

Trousseau syndrome is strongly associated with occult visceral adenocarcinoma (eg, pancreas, lung); it may be related to malignancy-associated mucin secretions that generate platelet-rich microthrombi.  In addition to venous thrombosis (deep and superficial), complications include verrucous endocarditis, ischemic stroke, and arterial emboli.  In this patient with malignancy risk factors (eg, smoking history, older age), the presence of epigastric pain despite antacid therapy raises concern for pancreatic cancer, which is classically associated with Trousseau syndrome.  CT scan of the abdomen should be prioritized.

(Choice A)  Peripheral septic thrombophlebitis is most often associated with breaks in the skin due to catheters, venipuncture, or intravenous injections.  Patients often have fever and pain with swelling at the infection site.  However, this patient does not have fever or a history of catheterization or injection, making the diagnosis less likely and antibiotics unnecessary.

(Choice B)  Tobacco use is a risk factor for esophageal squamous cell carcinoma and adenocarcinoma.  However, upper gastrointestinal endoscopy is preferred over barium swallow when cancer is suspected because endoscopy allows direct visualization and biopsy of suspicious lesions.

(Choice C)  Trousseau syndrome is more commonly associated with pancreatic cancer than colon adenocarcinoma, which is diagnosed with colonoscopy.  Colonoscopy is appropriate in the setting of iron deficiency anemia, positive fecal occult blood testing, and/or new-onset constipation in a high-risk patient.  This patient's refractory epigastric pain raises stronger suspicion for pancreatic cancer; colonoscopy can be performed if initial CT scan of the abdomen is nondiagnostic.

(Choice E)  D-dimer testing is most useful in low-risk patients with suspected deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism; it would not be useful in this patient with known, visible thrombosis (ie, superficial thrombophlebitis).

(Choice F)  The chest pain this patient experienced 2 weeks ago was most likely due to superficial thrombophlebitis.  She has no signs or symptoms of heart failure or valvular disease (eg, peripheral edema, murmur) and does not require echocardiography.

Educational objective:
Trousseau syndrome manifests with chronic disseminated intravascular coagulopathy and should be suspected in the setting of recurrent, migratory superficial thrombophlebitis.  It is strongly associated with pancreatic cancer and other adenocarcinomas (eg, lung) and should prompt diagnostic work-up (eg, CT scan of the abdomen) based on symptoms and risk factors.

questionList.questionText: A 45-year-old man comes to the physician due to epigastric pain and diarrhea.  Past medical history is significant for peptic ulcer disease.  He has a 20-pack-year smoking history but does not use alcohol or illicit drugs.  Physical examination shows abdominal tenderness without rebound or rigidity.  Endoscopy shows prominent gastric folds, 3 duodenal ulcers, and upper jejunal ulceration.  Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient's clinical findings - recurrent peptic ulcer disease with multiple ulcers and jejunal ulceration - suggest gastrinoma (Zollinger-Ellison syndrome [ZES]).  ZES is usually sporadic but is found in conjunction with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 (MEN1) in 20% of cases.  Gastrinomas usually occur in patients age 20-50 with dyspepsia, reflux symptoms, abdominal pain, weight loss, diarrhea, or frank gastrointestinal bleeding.  Endoscopy often shows thickened gastric folds, multiple peptic ulcers, refractory ulcers despite proton pump inhibitor (PPI) use, or ulcers distal to the duodenum in the jejunum (suggesting excess gastric acid that cannot be fully neutralized in the duodenum).

Fasting serum gastrin level (off PPI therapy for 1 week) should be checked in suspected gastrinoma; a level <110 pg/mL rules it out, and a level >1000 pg/mL is strongly suggestive, although gastric pH should also be measured as gastrin may also be elevated due to failure of gastric acid secretion (achlorhydria).  A gastrin level of 110-1000 pg/mL is nondiagnostic and requires a follow-up secretin stimulation test.  Secretin inhibits gastrin release by normal gastric G cells but stimulates gastrin release by gastrinoma cells; therefore, secretin administration should not cause a rise in serum gastrin concentrations in patients with other causes of hypergastrinemia.

Gastrinomas are managed with high-dose PPI, with surgery (eg, exploratory laparotomy and resection) considered in patients with sporadic gastrinoma with no evidence of metastatic disease.

(Choice A)  The calcium infusion study is usually reserved for patients who have gastric acid hypersecretion and are strongly suspected of having gastrinoma despite a negative secretin test.  Calcium infusion can lead to an increase in serum gastrin levels in patients with gastrinoma.

(Choice B)  Jejunal ulcer biopsy would not likely be useful as jejunal ulcers are usually due to gastric acid hypersecretion rather than local tumor invasion.

(Choice C)  Serum chromogranin A is a marker for well-differentiated neuroendocrine tumors.  It is elevated in several conditions such as carcinoid tumors, hyperthyroidism, chronic atrophic gastritis, and even chronic PPI therapy.  For this reason, it is less sensitive and specific than measurement of serum gastrin level.  However, it may be used as a confirmatory test in nondiagnostic cases.

(Choice E)  Triple therapy (PPI, amoxicillin, and clarithromycin) treats Helicobacter pylori infection, which can cause gastric and duodenal ulcers.  However, this patient's diarrhea and multiple ulcers in different sites are more suggestive of gastrinoma.

Educational objective:
Gastrinoma (Zollinger-Ellison syndrome) should be suspected in patients with multiple stomach ulcers and thickened gastric folds on endoscopy.  The diagnosis is strongly suggested by a fasting serum gastrin level >1000 pg/mL.  Patients with nondiagnostic serum gastrin levels should be evaluated with a secretin stimulation test.

questionList.title: Zollinger ellison syndrome

questionList.questionText: A 70-year-old man comes to the office due to early satiety, nausea, and upper abdominal discomfort.  The symptoms started 3 months ago and have progressively worsened; the patient now cannot eat a full meal.  For the past week, he has been unable to consume any solid food without vomiting afterward.  The patient has also had a 13.5-kg (29.8-lb) weight loss during this period.  He does not have dysphagia, hematochezia, melena, or hematemesis.  The patient has been taking omeprazole for the past 3 months with no symptom relief.  He has a 30-pack-year history.  Temperature is 37.5 C (99.5 F), blood pressure is 132/78 mm Hg, pulse is 85/min, and respirations are 12/min.  Physical examination is significant for bilateral temporal wasting.  Heart and lung sounds are unremarkable, and there is no appreciable lymphadenopathy.  Abdominal examination is notable for epigastric fullness and tenderness on palpation.  A succussion splash is present.  Which of the following best explains this patient's symptoms?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient with abdominal distension and intractable postprandial vomiting has a succussion splash (splash sound heard when the patient's abdomen is rocked), indicating retained food in the stomach.  This presentation suggests gastric outlet obstruction (GOO) resulting from mechanical obstruction of the pylorus or duodenum.  The diagnosis is confirmed with upper endoscopy (although CT scan often shows gastric distension and air-fluid levels).

The etiology of GOO is broad (eg, peptic ulcer disease, bezoar, gastric polyps), but most cases result from malignancy, most commonly pancreatic adenocarcinoma with gastric or duodenal invasion.  Pancreatic cancer is of particular concern in this older patient (age >65) with a history of prolonged tobacco use, cachexia, and epigastric tenderness.  Pancreatic malignancy associated with GOO has a poor prognosis because the tumor is usually too advanced for surgical resection.  Palliative measures include endoscopic stent placement to relieve obstruction and enable food intake.

(Choice A)  Annular pancreas develops when the embryonic ventral pancreatic bud fails to rotate properly around the duodenum, encircling it instead.  Most patients are asymptomatic, or the anomaly presents early in life with GOO.

(Choice B)  A gastric bezoar is an accumulation of undigestible materials (eg, hair, foreign objects) in the stomach; it is a very rare cause of GOO.  Patients typically have an underlying motility disorder (eg, gastroparesis) or a history of gastric surgery, which this patient does not have.

(Choice C)  Acute gastric volvulus can cause GOO but typically presents acutely with severe abdominal pain and hematemesis.  Chronic volvulus may cause mild abdominal discomfort and early satiety; vomiting may be present but is not typically intractable.  This patient's cachexia, older age, and significant tobacco use make malignancy more likely.

(Choice E)  Large gastric or duodenal ulcers can be complicated by GOO, but they typically develop in the setting of long-standing heartburn (lacking in this patient).  Moreover, the proton pump inhibitor this patient has used for 3 months (omeprazole) would be expected to prevent the condition.

Educational objective:
Gastric outlet obstruction presents with early satiety, postprandial vomiting, and abdominal distension.  Most cases are caused by malignancy, commonly from pancreatic adenocarcinoma with gastric or duodenal invasion.  Pancreatic cancer should be suspected when a patient has risk factors (eg, older age, tobacco use) and signs (eg, cachexia) of malignancy.

questionList.title: Pancreatic cancer

questionList.questionText: A 35-year-old woman comes to the office for follow-up on genetic testing for Lynch syndrome.  She has no symptoms or medical problems and has never had surgery.  A Papanicolaou test was normal last month.  The patient takes a daily multivitamin and no other medications.  She does not use contraception as she has not been sexually active since separating from her husband last year.  The patient's mother, age 54, is receiving chemotherapy for colon carcinoma.  Her maternal uncle was diagnosed with colon cancer at age 49, but it is in remission; her first cousin died of colon cancer at age 36.  In addition to colon cancer, the patient is at greatest risk for which of the following conditions?
questionList.explanationText:
Common hereditary cancer syndromes

Syndrome

Associated neoplasms

Lynch syndrome

  • Colorectal cancer
  • Endometrial cancer
  • Ovarian cancer

Familial adenomatous polyposis

  • Colorectal cancer
  • Desmoids & osteomas
  • Brain tumors

von Hippel-Lindau syndrome

  • Hemangioblastomas
  • Clear cell renal carcinoma
  • Pheochromocytoma

Multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1

  • Parathyroid adenomas
  • Pituitary adenomas
  • Pancreatic adenomas

Multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2

  • Medullary thyroid cancer
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Parathyroid hyperplasia (type 2A)

BRCA1 & BRCA2

  • Breast cancer
  • Ovarian cancer

Lynch syndrome (eg, hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer) is an autosomal dominant cancer syndrome that predisposes individuals to colorectal cancer and other malignancies.  Genetic testing should be performed in patients with a strong family history of colon cancer (eg, >3 relatives involving multiple generations).  The condition is due to a germline mutation in a DNA mismatch repair gene.  Once the diagnosis of Lynch syndrome is established, patients should undergo screening for colon cancer with colonoscopy.

In addition to colon cancer, patients are at extremely high risk for endometrial carcinoma.  Endometrial cancer screening with annual endometrial biopsy should begin at age 30-35.  Ovarian cancer risk is also increased and may present at a relatively younger age.  Therefore, prophylactic hysterectomy and bilateral oophorectomy is recommended at age 40 or earlier if childbearing is complete.

(Choice A)  Breast carcinoma can be caused by BRCA1 and BRCA2 gene mutations, which also impart an increased risk of ovarian cancer.  There is no increased risk of colon cancer with these mutations.  It is unclear if patients with Lynch syndrome have an increased incidence of breast cancer.

(Choices B and G)  Clear cell renal carcinoma and pheochromocytoma can be due to von Hippel-Lindau syndrome.  This syndrome is also autosomal dominant but is not associated with colon carcinoma.

(Choice D)  Important risk factors for primary hepatocellular carcinoma include chronic hepatitis B and C infections.  Most secondary liver cancers originate from the colon, and this patient would be at risk for hepatic metastases if she had signs of colon cancer (eg, weight loss, bloody stools).

(Choices E, F, and G)  Multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 (MEN1) syndrome is characterized by parathyroid, pituitary, and pancreatic adenomas.  MEN2 syndrome is characterized by medullary thyroid cancer, pheochromocytoma, and parathyroid hyperplasia.  Both syndromes are autosomal dominant, but colon cancer is not a feature.

Educational Objective:
Lynch syndrome causes colorectal cancer and imparts an extremely high risk of endometrial carcinoma for female carriers.  An annual endometrial biopsy, as well as prophylactic hysterectomy, is recommended to prevent endometrial cancer.

questionList.title: Lynch syndrome

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Lynch syndrome screening in the gynecologic tract: current state of the art.
ACOG Practice Bulletin No. 147: Lynch syndrome.

questionList.questionText: A 57-year-old man comes to the office due to constant middle and low thoracic back pain.  The pain started 4 weeks ago and has progressively worsened.  It is greatest at night, particularly when he lies down.  The patient has had no trauma to the back and has no bowel or bladder symptoms.  Review of systems is positive for a 4.5 kg (10 lb) weight loss and fatigue.  He has no chronic medical conditions and takes no medications other than a multivitamin.  The patient has smoked cigarettes since high school and occasionally drinks beer on weekends.  Temperature is 37 C (98.6 F), blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg, pulse is 80/min, and respirations are 16/min.  BMI is 28 kg/m2.  Examination of the spine shows no focal tenderness, and spinal range of motion is normal.  Straight leg raise testing does not elicit pain.  Muscle strength and sensation are intact in the lower extremities.  Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally.  Babinski sign is absent.  X-ray of the spine shows no abnormalities.  Complete blood count and serum creatinine are within normal limits.  Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questionList.explanationText:
Although back pain is common and often benign, this patient has several features that suggest a more serious pathology.  His smoking history, weight loss, and insidious back pain with normal neurologic and x-ray findings raise concern for pancreatic cancer in the tail of the pancreas.  Although tumors in the head of the pancreas are frequently associated with obstructive jaundice, steatorrhea, and epigastric pain, tumors in the body or tail of the pancreas may present with progressive, constant back pain that is worse at night when lying supine.

The pancreas lies in a retroperitoneal position against the posterior abdominal wall and is innervated by the splanchnic nerves (from T5-T10).  Pancreatic tumors often irritate visceral afferent fibers that conduct signals via the splanchnic nerve, leading to referred thoracic back pain.  Because this referred pain does not arise from a spinal pathology, spinal/neurologic examination and spinal imaging are generally normal.  CT scan of the abdomen, which has a sensitivity >90% for pancreatic lesions, is required.

(Choice A)  Epidural abscess is associated with insidious back pain, fatigue, and often normal x-ray findings (early in the course of the infection).  Most cases arise from hematogenous dissemination of bacteria, which can usually be identified with blood culture.  However, most patients have focal back pain on examination, and fever and lower extremity neurologic deficits are common.

(Choice B)  Bone marrow biopsy is required to diagnose multiple myeloma, which often presents with anemia, hypercalcemia, bone pain, and renal failure.  However, radiographic studies usually show lytic bone lesions.

(Choice D)  Physical therapy is sometimes used to treat acute lumbar radiculopathy (in addition to anti-inflammatory medications and early activity).  Although this patient's examination and radiographic studies are normal, the presence of significant weight loss, fatigue, and constant, progressive pain that is worse at night necessitates further workup for cancer.

(Choice E)  Sacroiliac joint imaging can help diagnose ankylosing spondylitis, an inflammatory joint disease that often presents with insidious back pain that is worse at night.  However, most cases arise in men age <40, the pain typically improves with activity, and spinal mobility (range of motion) is usually impaired.

(Choice F)  Upper endoscopy can identify gastric cancer, which is associated with weight loss and smoking.  However, most patients have microcytic anemia (due to tumor bleeding into the gastric lumen) and mid-epigastric pain.  Back pain is uncommon (because the stomach is intraperitoneal).

Educational objective:
Pancreatic cancer in the body or tail of the organ may present with constant, progressive back pain that is worse at night and when supine.  Because this is a referred pain, back/neurologic examinations and radiographic imaging are generally normal.  An abdominal CT scan is usually diagnostic.
questionList.subject: Surgery
questionList.title: Pancreatic cancer

questionList.questionText: A 68-year-old man comes to the office for follow-up for an abnormal finding on CT scan of the abdomen.  Two weeks ago, the patient was seen in the emergency department for left lower quadrant abdominal pain.  CT scan revealed acute sigmoid diverticulitis, which improved with oral antibiotics, as well as a cyst in the head of the pancreas.  The patient has no history of pancreatic diseases and reports no epigastric pain, diarrhea, or weight loss.  He used to drink alcohol heavily but stopped several years ago and does not smoke cigarettes.  Family history is unremarkable.  Vital signs are within normal limits.  Physical examination shows no abnormalities.  MRI of the abdomen confirms a 4.6-cm, multilocular cyst in the head of the pancreas with thickened walls.  The main pancreatic duct is mildly dilated.  Serum amylase, lipase, and liver chemistry studies are within normal limits.  Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Pancreatic cysts are common incidental findings, with an incidence of 40% in individuals age >70.  Risk for malignancy with any cyst is low; many can be managed conservatively (eg, reassurance, surveillance imaging).

However, some pancreatic cysts carry a risk for malignant transformation.  High-risk features on imaging include the following:

  • Large size (≥3 cm)
  • Solid components or calcifications
  • Main pancreatic duct involvement (ie, ductal dilation)
  • Thickened or irregular cyst wall

This patient's pancreatic cyst has several high-risk features (large size, main ductal dilation, thickened walls).  Because surgical cyst resection carries significant morbidity and mortality, further risk stratification is needed.  Therefore, endoscopic ultrasonography–guided fine-needle aspiration (and cytologic examination of aspirated fluid) is appropriate for determining whether surveillance or immediate resection is warranted based on cytology results.

(Choice B)  Benign pancreatic cystic lesions include serous cystadenoma, which appears as a honeycomb-like multicystic lesion, and pancreatic pseudocyst, which is a rounded, well-circumscribed fluid collection typically associated with chronic pancreatitis.  Patients with asymptomatic benign cysts can be reassured, but intervention may be needed for symptomatic (eg, abdominal pain) or rapidly enlarging lesions.  This patient's cyst contains high-risk features (eg, pancreatic ductal dilatation, thickened walls); reassurance is inappropriate.

(Choice C)  Screening for intracranial aneurysms is recommended for patients with autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD).  Although ADPKD can be associated with pancreatic cysts, it typically presents with hematuria, flank pain, hypertension, and chronic kidney disease earlier in life.  In addition, numerous renal cysts, absent in this patient, would be visible on CT scan.

(Choice D)  Serologic testing can help diagnose amebiasis due to Entamoeba histolytica.  Although amebiasis can cause abdominal pain, it presents with diarrhea (bloody or nonbloody), fevers, weight loss, and liver abscesses, not pancreatic cysts.

(Choice E)  Serum insulin, proinsulin, and C-peptide levels are used to diagnose insulinoma, a pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor that presents with hypoglycemia (not seen in this patient) and abnormally high levels of endogenous insulin (eg, elevated proinsulin and C-peptide).  On imaging, insulinomas are typically small (eg, <2 cm), hypervascular, solid nodules, instead of this patient's cystic lesion.

Educational objective:
Most pancreatic cysts are benign and can be managed conservatively (eg, reassurance, surveillance imaging); however, some with high-risk features (eg, large size, solid components or calcifications, main pancreatic duct involvement, thickened or irregular cyst wall) require further evaluation (eg, endoscopic ultrasonography–guided fine-needle aspiration) due to risk for malignant transformation.

questionList.title: Pancreatic cancer

answerChoiceList.choice: Serum insulin, proinsulin, and C-peptide level

questionList.questionText:
A 63-year-old man comes to the office due to anorexia and weight loss for the past 2 months.  He has no chest pain, abdominal pain, cough, or fever.  His medical problems include hypertension and latent tuberculosis treated 30 years ago.  He does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs.  Temperature is 37.5 C (99.5 F), blood pressure is 124/80 mm Hg, pulse is 78/min, and respirations are 14/min.  Physical examination reveals mucosal pallor and mild hepatomegaly.  The abdomen is soft, nondistended, and nontender.  Cardiopulmonary examination is normal.  Fecal occult blood testing is positive.  Laboratory results are as follows:

Complete blood count
    Hemoglobin9.8 g/dL
    Mean corpuscular volume72 µm3
    Platelets276,000/mm3
    Leukocytes6,700/mm3
Liver function studies
    Total bilirubin1.3 mg/dL
    Alkaline phosphatase190 U/L
    Aspartate aminotransferase (SGOT)32 U/L
    Alanine aminotransferase (SGPT)38 U/L

Ultrasound reveals a solitary liver lesion measuring 2x3 cm.  Which is the most likely diagnosis?
questionList.explanationText:
Solid liver masses

Focal nodular hyperplasia

  • Associated with anomalous arteries
  • Arterial flow & central scar on imaging

Hepatic adenoma

  • Women on long-term oral contraceptives
  • Possible hemorrhage or malignant transformation

Regenerative nodules

  • Acute or chronic liver injury (eg, cirrhosis)

Hepatocellular carcinoma

  • Systemic symptoms
  • Chronic hepatitis or cirrhosis
  • Elevated ɑ fetoprotein

Liver metastasis

  • Single/multiple lesions
  • Known extrahepatic malignancy

Metastatic disease is the most common cause of liver mass and is much more common than primary liver cancer.  Undiagnosed colorectal cancer (CRC) is likely in this patient with a solitary liver mass, probable iron deficiency anemia (low mean corpuscular volume), and positive fecal occult blood screen.  Gastrointestinal malignancies, such as colorectal or pancreatic cancer, are the most frequent source of liver metastases as their venous drainage is through the portal system directly to the liver.  Lung, breast, and skin cancers (melanoma) often also spread to the liver.  The liver is a common site of metastatic disease due to its dual blood supply (systemic and portal) and hepatic sinusoidal fenestrations allowing for easier metastatic deposition.

Liver metastases are often clinically silent unless pressure on the liver capsule or obstruction of the biliary tree causes pain or jaundice.  Results of hepatobiliary laboratory testing (eg, alkaline phosphatase) may be normal or mildly elevated, even in the setting of heavy tumor burden.  Multiple hepatic nodules are typically seen in metastatic disease; however, solitary lesions are not uncommon.  If a primary tumor is identified (eg, with colonoscopy), liver biopsy is usually not needed.

(Choice A)  Hepatic angiosarcoma is a rare liver neoplasm more common in older men who have been exposed to toxins (eg, vinyl chloride gas, inorganic arsenic compounds, thorium dioxide).

(Choice B)  Cholangiocarcinoma typically presents with symptoms of biliary obstruction - jaundice, pruritus, light-colored stools, and dark urine.  The main risk factor is a history of primary sclerosing cholangitis.

(Choices C and D)  Focal nodular hyperplasia (FNH) and hepatic adenoma are usually benign liver tumors seen in young women.  FNH is typically asymptomatic; hepatic adenoma may cause right upper quadrant pain and is associated with oral contraceptive use.

(Choice E)  Primary hepatic tuberculosis is rare due to the low oxygen tension in the liver.  Even with disseminated tuberculosis, a solitary liver mass would be unlikely.

(Choice F)  Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) typically emerges from a chronically inflamed liver (eg, chronic hepatitis B or C infection).  HCC is the most common type of primary liver cancer but is a far less common cause of hepatic malignancy than metastasis from another source.  Microcytic anemia and a positive fecal occult blood screen make CRC more likely in this patient.

Educational objective:
The most common malignancy of the liver is metastasis from another primary source.

questionList.questionText: A 54-year-old man comes to the office due to intermittent episodes of blood in the stool over the past several weeks.  The blood is mixed in the stool, and he has also noticed bright red blood on the toilet paper.  The patient reports no prior medical conditions but has not seen a physician in many years.  Family history includes colon cancer in his paternal uncle.  Vital signs are within normal limits.  Physical examination shows a nondistended, soft, and nontender abdomen with no hepatosplenomegaly.  A palpable mass is present on digital rectal examination.  Flexible sigmoidoscopy confirms a fungating mass in the upper rectum; biopsy is consistent with adenocarcinoma.  Staging CT scans reveal no lung, liver, or bony metastases.  Which of the following is most appropriate prior to surgical treatment of this patient's condition?
questionList.explanationText:
Staging evaluation for rectal adenocarcinoma

Tumor markers

Carcinoembryonic antigen

Imaging

CT scan: chest, abdomen, pelvis

Endoscopy/direct visualization

Colonoscopy

This patient has adenocarcinoma of the rectum, presenting with rectal bleeding and confirmed on flexible sigmoidoscopy.  Sigmoidoscopy is generally well tolerated by patients and is an effective tool for evaluating lesions in the distal colon.  It can also be considered for colorectal cancer screening in low-risk individuals and has been shown to reduce colorectal cancer mortality.  The procedure can be performed in an office setting by gastroenterologists and trained primary care or advanced care providers.

However, abnormal results on sigmoidoscopy often require follow-up colonoscopy.  Sigmoidoscopy does not visualize beyond the rectosigmoid colon.  Patients with left-sided adenomas or adenocarcinomas have increased risk for synchronous neoplasia in the right colon and therefore require visualization of the entire colon with colonoscopy (Choice D).  In addition, the staging evaluation should include CT scans of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis to identify distant metastasis.  Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) levels are also helpful for prognostication, although they exhibit low sensitivity and specificity for metastasis.

(Choice A)  Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) is caused by mutations in the Adenomatous Polyposis Coli (APC) gene and confers a very high risk of colorectal adenocarcinoma.  However, affected individuals typically have numerous colon adenomas, not a solitary mass.  Also, a more extensive family history would be expected because FAP is autosomal dominant with nearly 100% penetrance.

(Choice C)  Patients with Lynch syndrome (hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer) are at increased risk for gastric adenocarcinoma and warrant periodic upper endoscopy to detect early adenomatous polyps.  However, patients typically have an extensive family history of colon, endometrial, ovarian, and stomach cancers across multiple generations.

(Choice E)  Lymphatic drainage from areas distal to the anal dentate line involves inguinal lymph nodes.  To rule out lymphatic metastasis in anal cancer, a sentinel inguinal lymph node biopsy is often obtained at the time of tumor resection.  This is unnecessary for rectal tumors proximal to the anal dentate line because lymphatic drainage from this region goes to the inferior mesenteric and internal iliac, but not the inguinal, lymph nodes.

Educational objective:
Sigmoidoscopy is an effective tool for evaluating lesions in the distal colon but does not visualize the right colon.  Patients with left-sided adenomas or adenocarcinomas detected on sigmoidoscopy have increased risk for synchronous neoplasia on the right side and require visualization of the entire colon with colonoscopy.
